metadata.title: Convert Joules to Calories – Energy Converter
metadata.description: Convert energy from Joules (J) to Calories (cal), useful for nutrition and chemistry reference.

introduction: This converter transforms energy measurements from joules (SI unit) to calories (nutrition unit).
Food energy is expressed in calories while scientific work uses joules.
This converter uses the relationship where 1 calorie equals approximately 4.184 joules.
methodology: 1 cal = 4.184 J. To convert joules to calories, divide by 4.184.
Calories in nutrition labels are kilocalories (kcal). 1 food calorie = 1 kilocalorie = 1000 calories.
Understanding joule-to-calorie conversion is useful for chemistry and nutrition contexts.
This converter provides precise energy conversion for scientific reference.
examples: Example 2 – Food calorie: 4.184 J = 1 calorie (small cal).
Example 3 – Nutritional energy: 4,184 J = 1,000 calories = 1 kilocalorie (food Cal).

faqs.question: What is a calorie?
faqs.answer: Energy to raise 1 gram water by 1°C. SI equivalent is joule (more commonly used in science).

faqs.question: What's the difference between cal and Cal?
faqs.answer: Small 'cal' (calorie) = 4.184 J. Large 'Cal' (kilocalorie, food calorie) = 4,184 J.

faqs.question: Why is food labeled in calories?
faqs.answer: Historical convention. US still uses kilocalories (called 'calories') on food labels.

faqs.question: Are food calories the same as chemistry calories?
faqs.answer: No. Food labels use kilocalories (1 kcal = 1,000 small calories). Can cause confusion.

faqs.question: How many calories should I eat daily?
faqs.answer: 2,000-2,500 for average adult. Varies by age, sex, activity level, metabolism.

faqs.question: Does 1 calorie burn if I burn 1 calorie?
faqs.answer: Misleading. Food labels use kcal. Burning '100 calories' means burning ~418,400 joules.

faqs.question: Why did science abandon calories?
faqs.answer: Joules are SI standard unit. More consistent with other physics units.

faqs.question: How is food energy measured?
faqs.answer: Bomb calorimeter: burn food, measure heat released. Results in kilocalories per serving.
